pullRequest.title: [DOCS] Adds feature encoding documentation under Concepts
pullRequest.bodyText:
Overview
This PR adds the high-level description of feature encoding as a new page under the Concepts section. The text highlights that it happens automatically.
Preview

Feature encoding
Concepts

commit.message: [DOCS] Adds feature encoding description to classification conceptual.

nodes.bodyText:
I don't understand what you are trying to say here. Here is some more information that you might want to include.
When the model makes predictions on new data, the data needs processing in the same way in which it is trained.
Machine learning model inference in the elastic stack does this automatically. Meaning, the automatically applied encodings are used in each call for inference.
When feature importance is calculated, we calculate the feature importance for the original categorical fields. Not the automatically encoded features.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -65,6 +65,24 @@ have a similar number of data points for each class.
 ////
 
 
+[[dfa-classification-feature-encoding]]
+=== Feature encoding
+
+Every {ml} model can only work with numerical values. For this reason, it is 
+required to transform the categorical values of the relevant features into 
+numerical ones. This process is called feature encoding.
+
+{dfanalytics-cap} automatically performs feature encoding. During which the 
+input data is pre-processed with the following encoding techniques:
+
+* one-hot encoding,
+* target-mean encoding,
+* frequency encoding.
+
+After the {classification} model performed the prediction, {dfanalytics} maps 
+the numerical output provided by the model to the categorical labels.

nodes.bodyText: I think a small description what each of these mean would be good. Or at least links to some nice descriptions.

@@ -65,6 +65,36 @@ have a similar number of data points for each class.
 ////
 
 
+[[dfa-classification-feature-encoding]]
+=== Feature encoding
+
+Every {ml} model can only work with numerical values. For this reason, it is 
+required to transform the categorical values of the relevant features into 
+numerical ones. This process is called feature encoding.
+
+{dfanalytics-cap} automatically performs feature encoding. During which the 
+input data is pre-processed with the following encoding techniques:
+
+* one-hot encoding: It is the process of assigning vectors consist of 0 and 1 to 
+  each category. The vector represent whether the corresponding feature is 
+  present (1) or not (0). The number of vectors correlates to the number of

+

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -65,6 +65,36 @@ have a similar number of data points for each class.
 ////
 
 
+[[dfa-classification-feature-encoding]]
+=== Feature encoding
+
+Every {ml} model can only work with numerical values. For this reason, it is 
+required to transform the categorical values of the relevant features into 
+numerical ones. This process is called feature encoding.
+
+{dfanalytics-cap} automatically performs feature encoding. During which the 
+input data is pre-processed with the following encoding techniques:
+
+* one-hot encoding: It is the process of assigning vectors consist of 0 and 1 to 
+  each category. The vector represent whether the corresponding feature is 
+  present (1) or not (0). The number of vectors correlates to the number of 
+  categories and the number of relevant features.
+
+* target-mean encoding: In this method, the categorical values are replaced by 
+  the mean value of the target variable.
+  
+* frequency encoding: This encoding technique takes into account how many times 
+  a given categorical value is present in relation with a feature.
+
+When the model makes predictions on new data, the data needs to be processed in 
+the same way in which it is trained. {ml-cap} model <<ml-inference,inference>>

nodes.bodyText: This looks like the same information as above.  If so, I think it should be re-used instead of restated in both places.  You might also consider moving this to a separate concept (like feature importance).  The regression and classification concepts feel like they're getting overlarge.

commit.message:
Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: Lisa Cawley <lcawley@elastic.co>
[DOCS] Moves feature encoding to a separate section under concepts.
